After an investigation into the events during the match, [[UEFA]] fined the [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] 100,000 [[Swiss francs|CHF]] ([[United States dollar|US$]]87,000) and warned that any future incidents would be punished more severely.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1798795,00.html|title=European Soccer's Racism Problem|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=2 December 2005|publisher=Deutsche Welle}}</ref> The incident even drew reactions from then-[[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[Tony Blair]] and Sports Minister [[Richard Caborn]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/spain/article/0,2763,1354973,00.html |title=Spanish apologise for soccer racism|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=19 November 2004|author=Paul Kelso and [[Giles Tremlett]]|work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> with the latter making the claim that the behaviour of Spanish fans was 20 or 30 years behind that of their British counterparts.<ref>{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Kelso |author2=[[Giles Tremlett]] |title=Spanish apologise for soccer racism |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/nov/19/football.spain |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=19 November 2004 |accessdate=2008-08-05 | location=London}}</ref> UEFA noted that possible punishments could include suspension from major international tournaments or the closure of Spain home international matches to supporters. On 7 February 2007, Aragonés won an appeal over the offence, with the misdemeanour being downgraded to "conduct which could be considered to be racist".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6338381.stm|title=Aragones wins Henry case appeal|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=7 February 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
In February 2005, [[Samuel Eto'o]] received racially driven verbal abuse from some [[Real Zaragoza]] spectators during a match for [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]. The fans began making monkey-like chants whenever Eto'o had possession of the ball and peanuts were hurled onto the pitch. Eto'o threatened to leave the pitch in the middle of the game, but was prevented by the intervention of his teammates and the referee, who rushed to the pitch to calm him down. His black teammate [[Ronaldinho]], who has suffered similar abuses but less intensely, said he was fed-up with the sounds and that if Eto'o had left the pitch, he would have done the same. As Barcelona won 4–1, Eto'o danced like a monkey, saying rival fans were treating him as a monkey.<ref name = "Eto'o responds to racist abuse">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/4261881.stm |title=Eto'o responds to racist abuse|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=13 February 2005|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Referee Fernando Carmona Méndez did not mention the incidents in his match report, commenting only that the behaviour of the crowd was "normal".<ref name="Eto'o responds to racist abuse"/> The fans were identified to police by fellow spectators and they were fined and banned from attending sporting events for five months.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/4104067.stm|title=Two fined for Eto'o taunts|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=17 December 2004|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Eto'o declared in the aftermath that the punishment was insufficient and that [[La Romareda]], Real Zaragoza's stadium, should have been closed for at least one year. However, Eto'o's coach, [[Frank Rijkaard]], told him to concentrate on football and to stop talking about the incident. Eto'o has stated that he does not take his children to football matches due the prevalent racism<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/6525401.stm|title=Eto'o keeps kids from racist fans|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=4 April 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref> and has also suggested that players walk off if they become victims of racism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/6262526.stm|title=Eto'o seeks racism walk-off|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=7 May 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
Many other African footballers have also been victims of racial abuse, such as the Cameroonian [[Idriss Carlos Kameni|Carlos Kameni]], who was abused while playing for [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] against [[Atlético Madrid]], who were fined €6,000.<ref name = "Racism in European football"/>
In January 2009, the Royal Spanish Football Federation fined [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] approximately US$3,900 after a group of fans made [[fascism|fascist]] gestures and chanted fascist slogans at a match. Match referee Alfonso Pérez Burrull cited "extremist or radical symbolism", and chants making reference to "the gas chamber."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/other/story/9189866/Major-racist-incidents-in-European-soccer|title=Major racist incidents in European soccer|accessdate=11 March 2009|date=6 February 2009|publisher=Fox Sports}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On 27 April 2014, Barcelona player [[Dani Alves]] was targeted by [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]] fans, who threw a banana at him. Alves picked up the banana, peeled it, and took a bite.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27183851|title=Dani Alves: Barcelona defender eats banana after it lands on pitch|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=29 April 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Teammate and also Brazilian player [[Neymar]]'s response, to post a photograph of himself on social media also eating a banana, went viral.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-27191333|title='We are all monkeys'|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=29 April 2014|author=Bruno Garcez|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Other footballers have also since taken photographs of themselves eating bananas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27194672|title=Dani Alves: Barcelona player backed by banana-eating stars|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=29 April 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> [[Cyrille Regis]], who had been racially abused while a player in the 1970s and '80s, expressed concern that the viral campaign would detract from the important issues of combating racism in the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27218472|title=Dani Alves: Keep focus on racism issue - Cyrille Regis|date=30 April 2014|accessdate=30 April 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Alves said that whoever threw the banana at him should be publicly shamed,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27204824|title=Dani Alves says banana thrower should be publicly shamed|date=29 April 2014|accessdate=29 April 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and on 30 April 2014, a man was arrested in connection with the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-27222240|title=Spanish police arrest Dani Alves banana thrower suspect|date=30 April 2014|accessdate=30 April 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Villarreal were later fined €12,000 for the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27316855|title=Dani Alves: Villarreal fined £9,850 for banana throw racism|date=7 May 2014|accessdate=7 May 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In early May 2014, Levante's [[Papakouli Diop]] complained of receiving racist abuse from opposition [[Atlético Madrid]] fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27279997|title=Atletico Madrid fans accused of racist chants by Levante's Diop|date=4 May 2014|accessdate=5 May 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27278148|title=Senegal's Diop complains of racist abuse from Atletico fans|date=4 May 2014|accessdate=5 May 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
===Sweden=== {{See also|Racism in Sweden|Football in Sweden}} In 2009, fans of Swedish football team [[IFK Göteborg]] abused supporters of rivals [[Malmö FF]] by referring to them as "''Rosengårdstattare''" ("[[Rosengård]] gypsies"), in a racist reference to the large immigrant population of [[Malmö]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Av Lars Johansson 26 FEBRUARI 18.00 |url=http://www.skanskan.se/article/20100226/MALMO/702269901/1057/*/supporter-hetsade-fore-fotbollsmatch |title=Malmö — Skånskan.se |publisher=Skanskan.se |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.anglarna.se/nyheter/artiklar/2264-qrosengardstattareq-en-omistlig-del-av-var-laektarrepertoar |title=Änglarna.se - "Rosengårdstattare" - en omistlig del av vår läktarrepertoar? |publisher=Anglarna.se |date=18 October 2009 |accessdate=2010-03-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110053348/http://www.anglarna.se/nyheter/artiklar/2264-qrosengardstattareq-en-omistlig-del-av-var-laektarrepertoar |archivedate=10 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Also, fans of [[Helsingborgs IF]] have been known to yell monkey chants at opposing dark-skinned players.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expressen.se/1.430395 |title=Rasistattack mot Blåvitts stjärna — Nyheter — Senaste nytt | Expressen — Nyheter Sport Ekonomi Nöje |publisher=Expressen.se |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref>
The Swedish National Team, in the Summer of 2018 posted a Youtube video of player Jimmy Durmaz making a statement against racism in soccer. Durmaz is Assyrian, but was born and raised in Sweden. Durmaz stated that, online, he had been called "darkie, bloody Arab, terrorist, Taliban."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/world-cup-swedish-squad-declares-f-racism-video-supporting-soccer-player-1123002|title=World Cup: Swedish Squad Declares "F*** Racism" in Video Supporting Soccer Player|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref> In the video, Durmaz talks about his family and how they have also been targets of racism. In the End Durmaz says "vi är eniga, vi är sverige, knulla rasism"<ref name=":9">{{Citation|last=Guardian Football|title=Sweden midfielder Jimmy Durmaz makes powerful statement against racism after abuse|date=2018-06-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f55dcJZDhAc|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> Which translates to "We are United, We are Sweden, Fuck Racism"<ref name=":9" />
===Switzerland=== {{See also|Football in Switzerland}} [[Fwayo Tembo]] left [[FC Basel|Basel]] after he accused club coach [[Thorsten Fink]] of making racist remarks towards him during a training session. Fink is reported to have told a collaborator to "get the monkey down from the tree".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gsp.ro/fotbal/liga-1/fotbalistul-dorit-de-becali-a-regresat-in-cariera-dupa-ce-a-fost-victima-rasismului-jos-cu-maimuta-din-copac-364947.html|title=Fotbalistul dorit de Becali a regresat în carieră după ce a fost victima rasismului: "Jos cu maimuţa din copac!"|publisher=Gazeta Sporturilor|work=gsp.ro|accessdate=9 October 2012|language=Romanian}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{See also|Racism in the United Kingdom|Football in the United Kingdom}}
====England==== {{See also|Football in England}} The [[Commission for Racial Equality]] (CRE), the Football Supporters Association (FSA) and the [[Professional Footballers' Association]] (PFA) have all launched initiatives in a bid to encourage more people from ethnic minorities to attend matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sirc.org/publik/fvracism.html|title=Racism and football fans|accessdate=2008-02-17|publisher=Social Issues Research Centre}}</ref>
[[Arthur Wharton]], born in [[Ghana|Gold Coast]] (today's Ghana), was the world's first black professional footballer. He played as a goalkeeper for [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]]. Wharton was considered the first black professional footballer although he was pre-dated by [[Andrew Watson (footballer, born 1856)|Andrew Watson]], a Scottish amateur footballer. Other early non-white footballers include [[Walter Tull]] and [[Hong Y Soo]].<ref name = "Pioneering Black footballers">{{cite web|url=http://www.furd.org/default.asp?intPageID=24|title=Pioneering Black footballers|accessdate=2008-02-17|publisher=[[Football Unites, Racism Divides]]}}</ref>
Dark-skinned [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] centre-forward [[Dixie Dean]] recalled how racist comments were aimed at him as he left the pitch at half time during a match in [[London]] in the 1930s. Dean reportedly punched the offender before disappearing into the players' tunnel. The authorities took no action against Dean, and a nearby police officer was alleged to have informed the victim that he had "deserved" his punishment.<ref name="Centre for the Sociology of Sport"/>
[[Steve Mokone]], a black South African who later was signed for, but never played for [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], left [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] after his manager allegedly said to him, "We brought you over here and you are not satisfied. That's the trouble with you people"; Mokone interpreted this as being racist, and he swiftly signed for Dutch side [[Heracles Almelo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knet.co.za/orlandostadium/kalamazoo.htm|title=Steve "Kalamazoo" Mokone|accessdate=2008-02-17|publisher=knet.co.za |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071007184844/http://www.knet.co.za/orlandostadium/kalamazoo.htm |archivedate = 7 October 2007}}</ref>
The player [[Roger Verdi]], who is of Indian origin, changed his name from Rajinder Singh Birdi due to racism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianfootball.com/features/interview/interview50.html|title=Interview with Roger Verdi|accessdate=2008-11-29|date=June 2007|author=Harmit Singh Kamboe|publisher=IndianFootball.com}}</ref>
In the 1960s, [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] players [[Clyde Best]], who is black and from [[Bermuda]], and [[Ade Coker]] were subjected to "monkey chants" and had bananas thrown at them during West Ham's games. Best had blamed this on the influence of the [[National Front (United Kingdom)|National Front]] on the football terraces.<ref name=clydebest>{{cite news|title=There should be no place for racism in football|url=http://www.sportsjournalists.co.uk/the-giller-memorandum/there-should-be-no-place-for-racism-in-football/|accessdate=7 November 2012|newspaper=www.sprotsjournalists.co.uk}}</ref>
In the 1980s, racism in football in England was rampant. [[Paul Canoville]] was abused by his own fans when he warmed up for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] before making his debut.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/3202229/Top-10-Football-hate-figures-Football.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Nick | last=Hoult | title=Top 10: Football hate figures | date=15 October 2008}}</ref> [[Garth Crooks]] was regularly subject to racist chants and banners from opposing fans during his time at Spurs. [[Cyrille Regis]] endured monkey chants from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] fans on his away début for West Bromwich Albion and was later sent a bullet in the mail following his call-up to the England squad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsjournalists.co.uk/other-bodies/football-writers/regis-on-big-ron-racism-and-death-threats-wrapped-in-a-bullet/ |title=Regis on Big Ron, racism and death threats sent with a bullet |work=Sportsjournalists.co.uk |date=9 September 2010 |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> In 1987 John Barnes was pictured back-heeling a banana off the pitch during a match for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] against Everton, whose fans chanted "Everton are white".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/barnes-there-are-lots-of-bad-white-managers-ndash-but-they-usually-get-second-chances-1773518.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Barnes: 'There are lots of bad white managers – but they usually get second chances' | date=18 August 2009}}</ref>
[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] striker [[Stan Collymore]] accused [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] defender [[Steve Harkness]] of racist abuse during a match at Villa Park in April 1998. In response, Harkness stated: "I vehemently deny the accusation that I made racist comments to Stan Collymore."<ref name=Colly>{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Paul|title=Football: Harkness denies racist slur|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-harkness-denies-racist-slur-1148631.html|accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=www.independent.co.uk|date=6 March 1998}}</ref>
On 21 April 2004, [[Ron Atkinson]] resigned from ITV after he was caught making a racist remark live on air about the black Chelsea player [[Marcel Desailly]]; believing the microphone to be switched off, he said, "...he [Desailly] is what is known in some schools as a fucking lazy thick [[nigger (word)|nigger]]." Although transmission in the UK had finished, the [[microphone gaffe]] meant that his comment was broadcast to various countries in the Middle East. He also left his job as a columnist for ''[[The Guardian]]'' "by mutual agreement" as a result of the comment.
In 2004, [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] became the first club to be charged by The Football Association over racist behaviour by their fans. The charges related to abuse aimed at Liverpool player [[Djimi Traoré]].<ref>{{cite news|title=FA charges Liverpool and Millwall|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/4081903.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=8 November 2012|date=9 December 2004}}</ref> On 13 January 2007, The FA charged Newcastle player [[Emre Belözoğlu]] with "using racially-aggravated abusive and/or insulting words", referring to an incident during the 3–0 defeat by Everton at [[Goodison Park]] on 30 December 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/6256787.stm|title=Newcastle's Emre denies FA charge|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=26 January 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Belözoğlu was, on 16 February 2007, accused of more racist behaviour, this time against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]]' [[El Hadji Diouf]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/6368207.stm|title=FA to probe new Emre race claims|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=16 February 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref> However, on 1 March 2007, it was revealed that Diouf would not be pursuing his claim.<ref name = "Emre faces new racism allegation">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/6407915.stm|title=Emre faces new racism allegation|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=1 March 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref> It was also later revealed that [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] player [[Al Bangura]] had released a statement declaring that he was the victim of racist abuse from Belözoğlu.<ref name="Emre faces new racism allegation"/> On 19 March he was cleared of the charges relating to the Everton game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/6468243.stm|title=Emre cleared of FA racism charge |accessdate=2008-02-17|date=19 March 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
In 2004, during a friendly match with Spain, English fans chanted racist comments towards the Spanish team and fans. This incident was widely condemned by the British government. This incident, although not a new manifestation, brought greater awareness in England to the problem of racism in sports.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ajcgermany.org/atf/cf/%7B46AEE739-55DC-4914-959A-D5BC4A990F8D%7D/DB%20Racism%20in%20European%20Soccer%20-%20for%20ajc.pdf|title=Antisemitism and Racism in European Soccer|last=Pallade|first=Yves|date=May 2007|website=American Jewish Community|access-date=October 16, 2018}}</ref>
On 6 March 2007, it was announced that the [[Metropolitan Police]] were investigating apparent anti-Semitic chants by West Ham fans before the match with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] two days previously after a video of the offence surfaced on the Internet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/6422059.stm|title=Police probe Hammers racism claim|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=6 March 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
On 7 April 2007, in a match between [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] and [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]], Gillingham keeper [[Kelvin Jack]] was racially abused by a Rotherham fan. On 13 April 2007, the fan was banned for life from the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/south_yorkshire/6551167.stm|title=Life ban for racist football fan|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=13 April 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
Following his appointment as manager in September 2007, Israeli [[Avram Grant]] has been the subject of anti-Semitic taunts from some Chelsea fans; Grant's father was a Polish survivor of the [[German Nazi]] [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/7020854.stm|title=Chelsea angry at Grant barracking|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=30 September 2007|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Grant has also received death threats and anti-Semitic post.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7254547.stm|title=Chelsea boss gets death threats|accessdate=2008-02-20|date=20 February 2008|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
In November 2008, [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]'s Egyptian forward [[Mido (footballer)|Mido]] was subjected to [[Islamophobia|Islamophobic]] chanting from a small number of Newcastle fans. Mido had been subjected to similar chants the previous year, again from Newcastle fans<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/other/story/9189866/Major-racist-incidents-in-European-soccer|title=Major racist incidents in European soccer|accessdate=11 March 2009|date=6 February 2008|publisher=Fox Sports}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and also in 2007 by [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] fans and West Ham fans who had referred to Mido as a "shoe bomber" in reference to his likeness to [[Richard Reid]], the British terrorist jailed in 2003.<ref name=Shoe-bomber>{{cite news|last=Hardy|first=Martin|title=I just wanted to silence the drunkards, says Mido|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-478140/I-just-wanted-silence-drunkards-says-Mido.html|accessdate=7 November 2012|newspaper=www.dailymail.co.uk|date=28 August 2007}}</ref>
During a [[2009–10 Football League Cup|League Cup]] match between [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] at the [[Britannia Stadium]] on 22 September 2009, Blackpool player [[Jason Euell]], who at the time was sat on the substitutes bench was racially abused by a Stoke fan, who was ejected from the stadium and subsequently arrested by [[Staffordshire Police]] before being released pending inquiries.<ref name="gazette5683253">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/sports-news/Racist-fans-should-go-to.5683253.jp|title=Racist fans 'should go to prison'|date=28 September 2009|work=[[Blackpool Gazette]]|accessdate=29 September 2009}}</ref> Euell confronted the supporter that was taunting him. Blackpool manager [[Ian Holloway]], who had to restrain Euell, was furious in his post-match interview, saying: <blockquote> We are human beings and Jason is a footballer. The colour of his skin shouldn't matter. It was disgusting. The stewards believed what Jason said, got the bloke out and I hope he is banned for life. [He is] an absolute disgrace of a human being. I thought those days had gone. Jason was just sat in the dugout at the time. I saw his reaction and I had to calm him down. It's absolutely disgraceful.<ref name="gazette5670407">{{cite news|url=http://www.blackpoolgazette.co.uk/sports-news/Holloway-slams-39disgusting39-attack.5670407.jp|title=Holloway slams 'disgusting' attack|last=Canavan|first=Steve|date=22 September 2009|work=[[Blackpool Gazette]]|accessdate=29 September 2009}}</ref> </blockquote> Euell, who received an official apology from Stoke City, later said: <blockquote> It did hurt. I felt I had to stand up for all colours and creeds and show that we won't accept it. I'm proud that I made a stand. It was a shock to hear what came out of the guy's mouth. Racism in football is not dead and buried but it's still a shock to hear that kind of thing in close proximity. There were people near the idiot who didn't agree with it, but there were others who turned a blind eye, which was disappointing.<ref name="guardian090924">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/sep/24/jasone-euell-racism-blackpool-stoke-city|title=Jason Euell insists he has no regrets about confronting racist supporter|date=24 September 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=29 September 2009 | location=London}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> </blockquote> In the wake of the incident, Spurs manager [[Harry Redknapp]] called for fans who racially abuse players to be imprisoned: "That is disgusting – there's no place for that in the game. Surely we can't have that sort of behaviour now? Anyone who does it should be put in prison – not banned from football. Stick them where they belong, in the nut-house. It's wrong."<ref name="gazette5683253"/>
In April 2011, an initiative was launched by comedian [[David Baddiel]] to tackle anti-semitism in the sport, which was backed by players including [[Frank Lampard]], [[Ledley King]] and [[Kieran Gibbs]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13086148.stm|title=Top players back David Baddiel's anti-semitism campaign|accessdate=17 April 2011|date=14 April 2011|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In April 2011, two followers of [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] were arrested before the start of a game against [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] after racially abusing a young black Torquay player who was taking part in the pre-match entertainment. Offenders Trevor Laughton and Joanne Worrall were subsequently banned from watching football or from approaching the venue of any Chesterfield matches for three years.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/local/two_football_fans_who_used_racist_abuse_get_match_bans_1_3476089 |title=Two football fans who used racist abuse get match bans - Local |publisher=The Star |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref>
On 15 October 2011, Liverpool's [[Luis Suárez]] was accused of racially abusing [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]'s [[Patrice Evra]],<ref name="FA Evra">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15324927.stm |title= The FA will look into claims Luis Suárez racially abused Patrice Evra |publisher = BBC Sport |date= 16 October 2011}}</ref> and The FA opened up an investigation into the incident.<ref name="FA Evra"/> On 16 November, The FA announced they would be charging Suárez, while Liverpool announced support for their player.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/nov/16/luis-suarez-liverpool-fa-racism|title=Liverpool's Luis Suárez will plead not guilty to FA racism charge|work=The Guardian|date=16 November 2011|author=Daniel Taylor|location=London}}</ref> On 20 December, The FA concluded a seven-day hearing, eventually fining Suárez £40,000 and banning him for eight matches for racially abusing Evra.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/16186556.stm|title=Liverpool striker Luis Suarez handed eight-match FA ban|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 December 2011}}</ref> Suárez had used the word "negrito" towards Evra, meaning "little black man" in Spanish. Suárez claimed that he meant the term to be taken as it is purportedly used in South America, as a term of endearment, but this explanation was not accepted by The FA.<ref name=Negrito>{{cite news|last=Herbert|first=Ian|title=Suarez 'only has himself to blame' for storm over alleged slur|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/suarez-only-has-himself-to-blame-for-storm-over-alleged-slur-6263926.html|accessdate=7 November 2012|newspaper=www.independent.co.uk|date=18 November 2011}}</ref>
On 23 October 2011, in a match between [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] and Chelsea, QPR's [[Anton Ferdinand]] alleged racial abuse by Chelsea captain [[John Terry]], claiming Terry called him a "fucking black cunt" during the game, a claim denied by Terry.<ref name=fbc>{{cite news|last=Fifield|first=Dominic|title=John Terry to learn fate after alleged racial slur of Anton Ferdinand|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/oct/24/john-terry-anton-ferdinand-chelsea-qpr|accessdate=2 November 2011|newspaper=guardian.co.uk|date=24 October 2011|location=London}}</ref> On 1 November, the [[Metropolitan Police]] announced a formal investigation into the allegations.<ref name=MP>{{cite news|title=John Terry to face police investigation over race allegations|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15548056.stm|publisher=BBC|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref> In January 2012, Ferdinand received death threats and a bullet was sent to him through the post.<ref name=Bullet>{{cite news|last=Burt|first=Jason|title=QPR defender Anton Ferdinand receives a bullet in the post ahead of Chelsea FA Cup match|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/queens-park-rangers/9045356/QPR-defender-Anton-Ferdinand-receives-a-bullet-in-the-post-ahead-of-Chelsea-FA-Cup-match.html|accessdate=8 November 2012|newspaper=www.telegraph.co.uk|date=27 January 2012}}</ref> On 1 February 2012 at [[Westminster Magistrates Court]], Terry was accused of a racially aggravated public order offence in relation to the game at [[Loftus Road]] on 23 October. He entered a not-guilty plea and [[R v Terry|stood trial]] on 9 July.<ref>{{cite news|title=John Terry denies Anton Ferdinand racism charge|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-16825874|publisher=BBC news|accessdate=1 February 2012|date=1 February 2012}}</ref> On 13 July, after a four-day trial, Terry was acquitted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/Resources/JCO/Documents/Judgments/r-v-john-terry.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713143737/http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/Resources/JCO/Documents/Judgments/r-v-john-terry.pdf |archivedate=13 July 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> In July, following the court hearing, Terry was charged by The FA with "using abusive and/or insulting words and/or behaviour towards Ferdinand and which included a reference to colour and/or race contrary to FA Rule E3[2]". In September 2012, after a four-day hearing, he was found guilty, banned for four games and fined £220,000.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Terry banned and fined by FA over Anton Ferdinand incident|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19723020|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref> Evidence in his defence at Terry's trial had been given by his teammate [[Ashley Cole]]. Ferdinand's brother [[Rio Ferdinand|Rio]] later referred to Cole via [[Twitter]] as a "choc ice", meaning someone who is black on the outside but white on the inside. In August 2012, The FA found this to be a reference to ethnic origin, colour or race and fined Ferdinand £45,000.<ref name=Choc-ice>{{cite web|title=Rio Ferdinand fined £45,000 by FA over 'choc ice' tweet|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/9482601/Rio-Ferdinand-fined-45000-by-FA-over-choc-ice-tweet.html|publisher=www.telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=8 November 2012|date=17 August 2012}}</ref>
On 29 May 2012, the BBC reported that [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] had conceded, in a response to a solicitor's letter from [[Jonathan Tehoue]], that manager [[Paolo Di Canio]], a self-described [[fascism|fascist]], had made an inappropriate remark to the player which Tehoue deemed to be racist. Before this news had broken, Swindon's chairman had been quoted as being entirely supportive of Di Canio and had denied that the manager had racially insulted Tehoue.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roan |first=Dan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18245752 |title=BBC Sport - Paolo Di Canio: Swindon apologised for 'inappropriate' comment |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> In October 2013, six supporters of [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] were sent to prison having been found guilty of racially aggravated fear of violence. The supporters had been on a train returning from a game against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] singing songs glorifying Gary Dobson, the racially motivated murderer of [[Murder of Stephen Lawrence|Stephen Lawrence]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-24746019 | title=Football fans jailed for abusive Stephen Lawrence chants | publisher=BBC News | accessdate=31 October 2013}}</ref>
In March 2014, [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] players [[Carl Ikeme]] and [[George Elokobi]] stated they were racially abused by opposition fans while playing away at [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26516307|title=Wolves complain to Walsall and FA about racial abuse|date=10 March 2014|accessdate=27 March 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> No action was taken against the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26650384|title=Walsall to face no action over Wolves racist abuse complaint|date=19 March 2014|accessdate=27 March 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
In August 2014, [[Malky Mackay]] and [[Iain Moody]] were accused of sending each other racist, sexist and homophobic text messages. Moody left his job as sporting director of [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] as a result.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28880830|title=Malky Mackay text claims: Iain Moody leaves Crystal Palace|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|author=David Ornstein|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Mackay apologised for the texts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28890833|title=Malky Mackay: Ex-Cardiff boss sorry for two 'disrespectful' texts|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The [[League Manager's Association]] defended Mackay, claiming that the texts were merely "banter"; the LMA had to later apologise for this as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28896425|title=Malky Mackay: LMA apologises for statement over text 'banter'|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28898540|title=Malky Mackay texts: Cardiff want LMA chief Richard Bevan to resign|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Mackay later denied being racist, sexist or homophobic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28904368|title=Malky Mackay: 'I'm not racist nor sexist'|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In September 2014, Liverpool player [[Mario Balotelli]] was subjected to racist abuse on Twitter following his tweet mocking Manchester United. Balotelli had tweeted "Man Utd... LOL'", following their 5–3 defeat to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/11112355/Mario-Balotelli-the-subject-of-racist-Twitter-abuse-after-mockery-of-Manchester-United.html|title=Mario Balotelli the subject of racist Twitter abuse after mockery of Manchester United|date=22 September 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref> Also in September 2014, [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] chairman [[Norman Smurthwaite]] considered appointing [[Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink]] as manager, but decided against it partly because he believed that a racist minority of the club's supporters would make appointing a black manager a poor idea.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chairman turned down Hasselbaink amid racist fan chants accusation|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Fans-beat-says-Vale-chairman-Smurthwaite/story-28322658-detail/story.html|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=The Sentinel|date=9 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211071907/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Fans-beat-says-Vale-chairman-Smurthwaite/story-28322658-detail/story.html|archivedate=11 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In February 2015, Chelsea fans were involved in an incident in which they pushed a black passenger off a [[Paris Métro|Métro]] carriage at [[Richelieu – Drouot (Paris Métro)|Richelieu-Drouot]] station in [[Paris]] before a [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] match against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]].<ref name=cfcmetro/> The supporters were heard chanting: "We're racist, we're racist, and that's the way we like it."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-31514168 |title=Film shows Chelsea fans in Paris Metro incident |work=BBC News |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref> Afterwards, Chelsea released a statement condemning the actions, and vowed to ban those involved.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2015/02/club-statement-.html |title=Club statement |publisher=chelseafc.com |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref> The incident prompted criticism from the football world. The FA condemned the incident, and backed Chelsea to take action. [[UEFA]] said they were "appalled" by the incident. [[FIFA]] President [[Sepp Blatter]] tweeted "there is no place for racism in football".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/feb/18/racist-chelsea-fans-push-black-man-paris-metro |title=Chelsea condemn fans who pushed black man off Paris Métro |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11668/9720021/police-hunt-for-chelsea-fans-involved-in-racist-paris-incident |title=Police hunt for Chelsea fans involved in racist Paris incident |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref> Chelsea later suspended three people from attending Chelsea games pending further investigation.<ref name="cfcmetro">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-31543951 | title=Chelsea FC suspends trio in 'racist' Paris Metro probe | publisher=BBC News | accessdate=27 February 2015}}</ref> In December 2017, at Prenton Park in an UEFA Youth League, Liverpool's [[Rhian Brewster]] was racially abused during the game.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hunter|first1=Andy|title=Liverpool to report Spartak Moscow over alleged racial abuse of Rhian Brewster|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/dec/06/liverpool-report-spartak-moscow-rhian-brewster-racial-abuse|website=Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> A [[North West Counties League]] game between [[Congleton Town F.C.|Congleton Town]] and [[Padiham F.C.|Padiham]] in October 2018 was abandoned in the second-half by the referee after the Padiham goalkeeper received racial abuse.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45773827]</ref>

====Scotland==== {{See also|Football in Scotland}} [[Andrew Watson (footballer, born 1856)|Andrew Watson]] was the first black football player to represent [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]. Watson never turned professional, however, so [[Arthur Wharton]] is sometimes reported as being the first black British footballer.<ref name = "Pioneering Black footballers"/>
The book ''Race, Sport and British Society'' says there was racist abuse of [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] player [[Paul Wilson (Scottish footballer)|Paul Wilson]] by [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] fans in the 1970s: "Rangers fans repeatedly bayed 'Wilson's a [[List of ethnic slurs#Paki|Paki]]' when Celtic played Rangers."<ref name="books.google.com">Ben Carrington and Ian McDonald [https://books.google.com/books?id=QakNM78bmm4C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false] (p.40)</ref> There have been reports that some Rangers fans used to sing "I'd rather be a darkie than a Tim",<ref>{{cite web |author=7.23.04 @ 12:01AM |url=http://spectator.org/archives/2004/07/23/waco-wars/1 |title=The American Spectator : Waco Wars |publisher=Spectator.org |accessdate=2010-03-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929000232/http://spectator.org/archives/2004/07/23/waco-wars/1 |archivedate=29 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>''Race, Sport and British Society'' by Ben Carrington and Ian McDonald, p. 40</ref><ref name="ZfYh7n2qTMC p. 83">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yZfYh7n2qTMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Sport+and+National+Identity+in+the+Post-War+World#v=onepage&q=darkie&f=false |title=''Sport and National Identity In the Post-War World'' by Adrian Smith and Dilwyn Porter, p. 83 |publisher=Books.google.com |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref> with "Tim" referring to a Celtic fan. The book ''Sport and National Identity In the Post-War World'' states, "black players in Scotland were greeted with bananas thrown from the crowd and a barrage of 'monkey grunts', notably [[Mark Walters]] of Rangers and [[Paul Elliott (footballer)|Paul Elliott]] of Celtic."<ref name="ZfYh7n2qTMC p. 83"/> On 2 January 1988, Rangers winger Mark Walters made his debut in the [[Old Firm]] derby match at [[Celtic Park]]. Rangers lost 2–0 and Walters was subjected to racist abuse from opposing Celtic fans, who were caught on camera chanting like monkeys, throwing fruit (mostly bananas), onto the pitch and dressing in monkey costumes.<ref name="news.scotsman.com">{{cite news|last=Smith |first=Andrew |url=http://news.scotsman.com/tacklingracisminscotland/A-black-day-for-Scots.3628273.jp |title=A black day for Scots football |work=News.scotsman.com |date= 30 December 2007|accessdate=2010-03-19 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref> It was reported that Rangers fans used "implicit racism" on the same day by singing "I'd rather be a darkie than a Tim".<ref name="ZfYh7n2qTMC p. 83"/> Although Celtic denounced the perpetrators, the [[Scottish Football Association]] (SFA) remained silent.<ref>{{cite news| first=| last=| author= Andrew Smith — The Scotsman | url= http://news.scotsman.com/tacklingracisminscotland/A-black-day-for-Scots.3628273.jp | title=A Black Day For Scottish Football | work=[[The Scotsman]]|date=December 2007 | accessdate=6 July 2008 | location=Edinburgh}}</ref> According to Walters, he experienced worse racial abuse in Edinburgh against [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]].<ref name="books.google.com"/> Following racist abuse aimed at Walters, Rangers banned some of their own season ticket holders.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |author=Sir Norman Chester Centre for Football Research |url=http://www.le.ac.uk/snccfr/resources/factsheets/fs4.html |title=Black Footballers in Britain — The Late 1980s and After — A 'New Era'? |publisher=[[University of Leicester]] |date=June 2002 |accessdate=6 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728140834/http://www.le.ac.uk/snccfr/resources/factsheets/fs4.html |archivedate=28 July 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> Andrew Smith from ''[[The Scotsman]]'' newspaper stated, "It is depressing to think that enforcement as much as enlightenment might account for Walters being the only black footballer in this country to have had bananas thrown at them."<ref name="news.scotsman.com"/>
Rangers captain [[Lorenzo Amoruso]] issued a public apology after a match in December 1999 for making racist comments against [[Borussia Dortmund]]'s Nigerian striker [[Victor Ikpeba]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-amoruso-apologises-for-racist-remarks-to-ikpeba-1131511.html |title=Football: Amoruso apologises for racist remarks to Ikpeba — Sport |work=The Independent |date=10 December 1999 |accessdate=2010-03-19 | location=London | first=Ken | last=Gaunt}}</ref> In March 2003, Rangers fans were accused of racially abusing [[Bobo Baldé]] and [[Mohammed Sylla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kickitout.org/news.php/news_id/2319 |title=Latest News |publisher=Kickitout.org |date=25 April 2002 |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Irvine |first=Neil |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2397771/Rangers-to-get-rid-of-racist-fans.html |title=Rangers to get rid of racist fans |work=Telegraph |date=11 March 2003 |accessdate=2010-03-19 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/scotland/article883171.ece | location=London | work=The Times | first1=Matthew | last1=Knowles | first2=Douglas | last2=Alexander | title=SFA to appoint racism officer | date=24 August 2003}}</ref><ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/mar/10/newsstory.sport6 |title=Rangers to root out racists |work=The Guardian |date=10 March 2003 |accessdate=2010-03-19 | location=London}}</ref> Rangers Chairman [[John McClelland (businessman)|John McClelland]] stated that, "There was such a crescendo during Saturday's match although I thought I heard noises of this kind I can't be 100% sure."<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> In May 2004, [[Marvin Andrews]] condemned racism from some Rangers fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kickitout.org/news.php/news_id/1379 |title=Latest News |publisher=Kickitout.org |date=12 May 2004 |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref>
In November 2004, then-manager of Celtic [[Martin O'Neill]] suggested [[Neil Lennon]] was the subject of chants of a "racial and sectarian manner".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/4036879.stm | work=BBC News | title=Celtic invited to make complaint | date=24 November 2004}}</ref>
During a [[2006–07 Scottish Cup|2007 Scottish Cup]] tie, [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]] player [[Jason Scotland]] was the target of racist taunts by a handful of [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] fans. The offenders were promptly reprimanded by the spectators around them and were reported to police and match stewards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/st_johnstone/6407259.stm|title=Scotland disappointed at racism|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=1 March 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Motherwell Chairman [[John Boyle (footballer, born 1946)|John Boyle]] later issued an apology on behalf of the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/motherwell/6407937.stm|title=Motherwell apologise for racism|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=1 March 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Motherwell were to court further controversy on 3 September 2007 when [[Laryea Kingston]] of Hearts was abused, although Motherwell refuted the claims.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/motherwell/6977160.stm|title=SPL seek reply to racism claims|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=6 September 2007|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
In October 2009, Rangers player [[Maurice Edu]] said he was racially abused by some Rangers fans while leaving [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox]] after a [[UEFA Champions League]] defeat by Romanian club [[FC Unirea Urziceni|Unirea Urziceni]].<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/> Edu wrote on [[Twitter]], "Not sure what hurt more: result or being racially abused by couple of our own fans as I'm getting in my car."
Three Scottish judges ruled in June 2009 that "[[Famine song|The Famine Song]]" is racist because it targets people of Irish origin.<ref name=legal>{{cite web|url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/103590-court-rules-famine-song-is-racist/|title=Court Rules Famine Song is Racist|work=stv|date=June 2009|accessdate=2009-08-04}}</ref><ref name=legal1>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/8109359.stm|title=Judges brand Famine Song 'racist'|work=BBC|date=June 2009|accessdate=2009-08-07}}</ref> George Peat, president of the SFA, has suggested that the song causes embarrassment for Scottish football and should be stamped out.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/scotland/article5026958.ece | location=London | work=The Times | first=Graham | last=Spiers | title=SFA president warns Rangers over Famine Song | date=28 October 2008}}</ref> Peat has also stated that the SFA is determined to contribute to the eradication of offensive songs from Scottish football.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/7693166.stm], [[BBC Sport]].</ref> In November 2008, a Rangers fan was found guilty of a breach of the peace (aggravated by religious and racial prejudice) for singing "The Famine Song" during a game against [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]].<ref>[http://www.kilmarnockstandard.co.uk/ayrshire-news/news-east-ayrshire/kilmarnock-news/2008/11/26/rangers-fan-guilty-over-singing-famine-song-at-rugby-park-81430-22348515/], ''Kilmarnock Standard''.</ref> It was widely reported after an Old Firm game in February 2009, Rangers fans had sung "The Famine Song" at Celtic Park.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/7894854.stm], [[BBC Sport]].</ref> ''The Famine Song'' was also sung in March 2011 at a Scottish football game by Rangers fans,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/culture/jmacmillan/100052373/is-it-now-officially-OK-to-sing-anti-irish-anti-catholic-hate-songs-in-scottishs-football-stadiums/ | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Is it now officially OK to sing anti-Irish, anti-Catholic hate songs in Scottish football stadiums? | date=29 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Custom byline text:  |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/comment/herald-letters/why-the-fans-who-sing-songs-of-hate-are-committing-an-offence-1.1093147 |title=Why the fans who sing songs of hate are committing an offence |publisher=Herald Scotland |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> nevertheless, Scottish Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskill described the match as a "great advert for Scottish football". <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2011/03/26/church-set-to-prepare-hate-song-dossier-as-fans-claim-cops-allowed-sectarianism-at-hampden-86908-23017130/ |title=Church to create 'hate song' dossier as fans claim cops allowed sectarianism at Hampden |publisher=The Daily Record |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> ''[[The Herald (Scotland)|The Herald]]'' journalist Doug Gillon has written that "the sectarian intolerance which divides Scottish society [...] is rooted in anti-Irish racism".<ref>{{cite web |author=Doug Gillon |url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/sport/headlines/display.var.2488389.0.Friendly_timing_could_not_be_worse_as_Spain_try_to_cast_off_racism_shame.php |title=Friendly timing could not be worse as Spain try to cast off racism shame |publisher=Theherald.co.uk |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=2010-03-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525035031/http://theherald.co.uk/sport/headlines/display.var.2488389.0.Friendly_timing_could_not_be_worse_as_Spain_try_to_cast_off_racism_shame.php |archivedate=25 May 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In February 2011, in an Old Firm match at Celtic Park, a Celtic supporter was caught mocking black Rangers player [[El Hadji Diouf]] with monkey noises and gestures as he was about to take a corner kick.<ref>{{cite news|author=Stephen Houston |url= |title=Shame of Race Yob |work=News of the World |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=}}</ref>
In April 2011, then-manager of Celtic Neil Lennon received an explosive device in the post. Brian McNally described this as due to "anti-Catholic and anti-Irish racism".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/opinion/blogs/mirror-football-blog/Brian-McNally-on-Celtic-Neil-Lennon-letterbombs-Why-ALL-football-fans-must-unite-against-football-terrorism-growing-out-of-sectarian-divides-in-Scotland-article726550.html |title=Brian McNally on Celtic Neil Lennon letterbombs Why ALL football fans must unite against football terrorism growing out of sectarian divides in Scotland - Mirror Football Blog |publisher=MirrorFootball.co.uk |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref> A number of high-profile Celtic fans also were sent suspected explosive devices. Leader of the Scottish Conservative Party Annabel Goldie MSP described bullets sent to Neil Lennon and a number of Celtic players as "racism and sectarianism".<ref name=GolLen>{{cite news|url=http://www.scottishconservatives.com/news/news/annabel-goldie-shows-racism-the-red-card/887 |title=Annabel Goldie shows racism the red card |work=Scottish Conservatives |date=January 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928180537/http://www.scottishconservatives.com/news/news/annabel-goldie-shows-racism-the-red-card/887 |archivedate=28 September 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> After an attempted assault on Neil Lennon at Hearts' [[Tynecastle Stadium]], a motion against anti-Irish racism was lodged in the Scottish Parliament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glasgowsnp.org/MSPs/Bob_Doris_MSP/Doris_leads_Parliament_in_support_of_Neil_Lennon/ |title=Scottish Independence - Doris leads Parliament in support of Neil Lennon |publisher=Glasgow SNP |date=12 May 2011 |accessdate=2012-06-03}}</ref>
In October 2014, Celtic player [[Aleksandar Tonev]] received a seven-match ban for racially abusing an opponent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29197915|title=SFA to assess Logan's allegation of Tonev racist slur|date=15 September 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29285903|title=Celtic: Aleksandar Tonev charged over alleged racism|date=19 September 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29374885|title=Celtic's Aleksandar Tonev given seven-game ban for racist abuse|date=30 October 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
In November 2018 [[Dennon Lewis]] spoke out about the racist abuse he has received from his club's (Falkirk's) own fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46372631|title=Falkirk's Dennon Lewis: 'Disgusting' racist abuse 'is a line crossed'|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
===Turkey=== {{See also|Racism in Turkey}}
On 15 April 2012, [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]]'s [[Emre Belözoğlu]] was accused of making racist comments on the pitch towards [[Trabzonspor]]'s [[Didier Zokora]]. After the match, Zokora told [[Digiturk|Lig TV]]: {{quotation | Emre and I came face to face during the match. I'll tell you what he said word for word. He called me: 'A fucking nigger'. This is the first time in my life something like this has happened to me. Emre has [[Ethnic groups of Africa|Africans]] like [[Joseph Yobo|Yobo]] and [[Moussa Sow|Sow]] as team-mates – I can't understand why he'd say such a thing. We're trying to get on with our jobs. What does the colour of our skin matter? Fans, [[FIFA]], the press are all against racist statements. I hope something like this doesn't go unpunished.<ref>{{cite news| date = 15 April 2012| url = http://www.goal.com/en-sg/news/3868/main/2012/04/16/3038805/trabzonspors-zokora-accuses-emre-of-racist-slur| title = Trabzonspor's Zokora accuses Emre of racist slur| work = goal.com| accessdate =15 April 2012 |quote = "Emre and I came face to face during the match. I'll tell you what he said word for word. He called me: 'A fucking nigger'," Zokora told Lig TV after the match.| location=London}}</ref>}}
Lip-reading professionals say Belözoğlu has said the words "fucking [[nigger]]". Emre received a two-game ban for his actions after it was concluded that he had used abusive, but not racist, language by the authorities. There are still questions about the low ban he received.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turkspor.net/detay.asp?id=68061|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505020943/http://www.turkspor.net/detay.asp?id=68061|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 May 2014|title=TFF HUKUK KURULU AĞIZ OKUMUŞ ve EMRE'nin "Sİ...MİN ZENCİSİ" DEDİĞİNİ TESBİT ETMİŞ.. SADECE O MU, DAHA DA FAZLASI VAR...|work=Turkspor.net|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref>
On 12 May 2013, before the match between Fenerbahçe and [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]], Galatasaray striker [[Didier Drogba]], along with his Ivorian international teammate [[Emmanuel Eboué]], were racially abused by certain Fenerbahçe fans during the pre-match warmups. They were allegedly shown bananas. Television cameras and some pictures clearly captured a fan waving around a banana. Though there were no monkey chants or gestures of that sort, the "banana" caused a huge controversy and Fenerbahce has been condemned. This is the second ever known racism incident in Turkey, again involving Fenerbahçe following the events that took place between Belözoğlu and Zokora in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccerwithoutlimits.com/racism-strikes-in-turkey-as-former-chelesa-man-didier-drogba-abused/26511/ |title=Racism Strikes in Turkey as Former Chelesa Man Didier Drogba Abused |publisher=Soccer Without Limits |date=12 May 2013 |accessdate=2013-05-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622223606/http://soccerwithoutlimits.com/racism-strikes-in-turkey-as-former-chelesa-man-didier-drogba-abused/26511 |archive-date=22 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fanatik.com.tr/sindirim-sistemim-bozuk_3_Detail_34_312581.htm |title=Sindirim sistemim bozuk |publisher=Fanatik.com.tr |date=16 May 2013 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22527009 |title=Galatasaray: Didier Drogba questions racists who abused him |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2013 }}</ref>
==Middle East== {{See also|Racism in the Middle East}}
=== Syria === A scandal took place during the 2018 World Cup qualifiers surrounding the match between Syria and Iran. The match was held in Kuala Lumpur during Monsoon season, making the match much more difficult and ending in a 0-0 tie. Iran then accused Syria of 'fixing' the game to prevent Iran from advancing to the World Cup. This event shows the underlying racial tension between Syria and Iran and exemplifies how racial discrimination works its way into the sport.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/blog/2016/11/28/conspiracy-and-heartbreak-this-week-in-middle-east-football|title=Conspiracy and heartbreak: This week in Middle East football|last=Levy|first=Uri|work=alaraby|accessdate=2017-04-24|language=en}}</ref>
===Israel=== {{See also|Racism in Israel|Football in Israel}} {{expand section|[[Beitar Jerusalem]]|date=January 2012}} Racist incidents date back to at least the 1970s, such as when [[Arab-Israeli]] player [[Rifaat Turk|Jimmy Turk]] joined [[Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C.|Hapoel Tel Aviv]]. Turk was subjected to [[anti-Arab racism|anti-Arab]] abuse during nearly every game he played.<ref name=ejp20060307>{{cite news|title=England and Israel join for anti-racism football campaign |url=http://www.ejpress.org/article/in_depth/world_cup/6624 |work=European Jewish Press |date=7 March 2006 |accessdate=2008-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120054813/http://www.ejpress.org/article/in_depth/world_cup/6624 |archivedate=20 November 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> According to Itzik Shanan, director of communications at the [[New Israel Fund]], among most racist fans are supporters of [[Beitar Jerusalem]], also Hapoel Tel Aviv fans have been using slogans promoting a Holocaust against [[Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Zalen |title=Israel joins fight against soccer racism |url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1161811247484&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=1 November 2006 |accessdate=2008-08-05 }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Israeli right-wing football supporters taunt Arab players during games, especially those who play for the mixed Arab-Jewish team [[Bnei Sakhnin]].<ref name=ejp20060307/> [[Ronny Rosenthal]], playing for Israel's [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] in 1989, was subjected to [[antisemitism|anti-Semitic]] taunts.<ref name = "Racism in European football">{{cite web |url=http://www.kickitout.org/232.php |title=Racism in European football |accessdate=2008-08-05 |publisher=Kick It Out}}</ref>
Under Israeli law, football fans can be prosecuted for incitement of racial hatred. The "New Voices from the Stadium" program, run by the [[New Israel Fund]] (NIF) amasses a "racism index" that is reported to the media on a weekly basis, and teams have been fined and punished for the conduct of their fans. According to [[Steve Rothman]], the NIF San Francisco director, "Things have definitely improved, particularly in sensitizing people to the existence of racism in Israeli society."<ref name="jweekly">[http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/34880/a-noble-goal-can-israel-give-soccer-racism-the-boot/ A noble goal: Can Israel give soccer racism the boot?], by Joe Eskenazi, JWeekly</ref> In 2006, Israel joined [[Football Against Racism in Europe]] (FARE), a network set up to counter racism in football.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/home/article.aspx?id=39740 Israel joins fight against soccer racism], by MATT ZALEN, Jerusalem Post</ref>
==Oceania==
===Australia=== {{See also|Racism in Australia|Association football in Australia}} At a 1994 match in Melbourne between the [[Croats|Croatian]] community supported [[Melbourne Knights]] and the [[Greeks|Greek]] community supported [[South Melbourne FC|South Melbourne]], many [[ethnic slurs]] were exchanged between the two sets of supporters.<ref>http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/FootballStudies/2001/FS0401e.pdf</ref>
==North America== {{See also|Racism in North America}}
===Mexico=== {{See also|Football in Mexico}} In the first day of the [[La Primera División|Apertura 2006]] tournament, fans of [[Santos Laguna]] made guttural sounds imitating a chimpanzee against the [[Panama]]nian player [[Felipe Baloy]] of [[C.F. Monterrey|Monterrey]] as he scored a goal. During the game, Santos Laguna's fans had also chanted other racial slurs towards Baloy, including "''chango''" ("monkey") and "''come platano''" ("banana eater").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/noticia.php?id_noticia=23981 |title=Medio Tiempo, la casa del futbol en Prodigy MSN |publisher=Mediotiempo.com |accessdate=2012-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070629003126/http://www.mediotiempo.com/noticia.php?id_noticia=23981 |archivedate=29 June 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The disciplinary commission of the [[Mexican Football Federation]] sanctioned the Santos club to a sum equivalent of 5,600 days of league minimum wage for the racist insults.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Sasaki |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2006/08/22/racism-in-mexican-football/ |title=Racism in Mexican Football |publisher=Global Voices Online |date=22 August 2006 |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref>
The racism went past the field in 2014 when Mexican politician, Carlos Trevino, called Brazilian football legend Ronaldinho an ape after he signed with a team in the Mexican league. He was quoted saying "I detest it all the more because people obstruct and flood the main avenues, causing me to spend two hours getting home … and all to see AN APE … A Brazilian, but an ape nonetheless. This has become a ridiculous circus." These outbursts were the reason why the Brazilian legend left the Mexican league after only one season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/sep/15/mexican-politician-ronaldinho-social-media|title=Mexican politician causes outrage after racist post about Ronaldinho|last=Tuckman|first=Jo|date=15 September 2014|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2017-04-24|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
===United States=== {{See also|Racism in the United States|Soccer in the United States}} Overt displays of racism at U.S. soccer matches are extremely rare compared to the EU and Russia, in part, because the fan base of soccer in the U.S. is ethnically diverse and much younger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://the18.com/news/how-diverse-soccer-united-states-really|title=How Diverse Is Soccer In The United States, Really?|publisher=}}</ref> However, during a 24 May 2008 [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) game between the [[Columbus Crew]] and the [[New England Revolution]], Revolution forward [[Kheli Dube]] (originally from Zimbabwe) scored a goal against the Crew in the 89th minute of the game. An unidentified fan in the audience shouted out a racist slur. The incident was subsequently posted to the video sharing website [[YouTube]], and MLS promised an investigation. In response to the epithet, Revolution player [[Shalrie Joseph]] reportedly made an obscene gesture towards the offending fan. Assuming that MLS could have identified the fan, Commisoner [[Don Garber]] promised to ban him.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press |url=https://www.thestar.com/Article/432190 |title=MLS investigating fan's slur captured on camera |publisher=thestar.com |date=28 May 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-19 | location=Toronto}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Goal.com Features |url=http://goal.com/en-us/news/145/goalcom-features/2008/05/30/716902/the-3-5-2-crewd-behavior-bad-yanks-and-mcreturn |title=The 3-5-2: Crewd Behavior, Bad Yanks and McReturn |publisher=Goal.com |date=30 May 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.mywire.com/a/AFP/US-soccer-promises-to-ban/6571332?extID=10051 |title=US soccer promises to ban racist fan — if they find him | AFP | MyWire Reference |publisher=Mywire.com |date=4 June 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref>
In July 2013, two former (caucasian) coaches of MLS side [[Chivas USA]] filled a discrimination suit against the team. In this suit, they claimed that Chivas had become a racist squad after ridding themselves of most non-Mexican players and coaching staff following several unsuccessful seasons. After the allegations were presented to a wider audience on HBO's "Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel", MLS released a statement saying, "MLS has zero tolerance for discrimination or prejudice of any kind... And although allegations in this lawsuit raise serious issues it would not be appropriate for us to say anything more while the litigation is ongoing." Nothing significant happened following the accusations.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Is This MLS Soccer Team Racist?|url = http://abcnews.go.com/ABC_Univision/chivas-usa-racist-soccer-team/story?id=19749008|website = ABC News|date = 23 July 2013|accessdate = 2016-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Major League Soccer releases statement concerning allegations of racism and discrimination at Chivas USA|url = http://www.thegoatparade.com/2013/7/29/4569558/major-league-soccer-releases-statement-chivas-usa-racism-discrimination-allegations-litigation|website = The Goat Parade|accessdate = 2016-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Watch HBO's Report on Chivas USA That Alleges Racial Discrimination at MLS Club [VIDEO]|url = http://worldsoccertalk.com/2013/07/24/watch-hbos-report-on-chivas-usa-that-alleges-racial-discrimination-at-mls-club-video/|website = World Soccer Talk|accessdate = 2016-01-22}}</ref>
==South America== {{See also|Racism in South America}}
===Argentina=== {{See also|Racism in Argentina|Football in Argentina}} On 14 April 2005, the [[Quilmes Atlético Club|Quilmes]] player [[Leandro Desabato]] was arrested for racially abusing [[Grafite]], a black Brazilian player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0512/p07s01-woam.html|title=Soccer slide-tackles racism|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=12 May 2005|author=Bill Faries|work=Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> He was held for 40 hours, but no charges were brought against him after Grafite decided not to press charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=soccer&id=2036949|title=Argentine player held in Brazil for racist insults|accessdate=2008-02-17|date=14 April 2005|author=Pedro Fonseca|publisher=ESPN}}</ref>
Damien Perez of Arsenal de Sarandi labelled his opponent Jerry Bengston a "negro de mierda", roughly translated to "negro piece of shit". This is a common racial slur in Latin America. One Argentinian player, Alberto Raimundi even felt it was appropriate to use the slur when describing an opponent during a post-game interview.<ref name="VICE Sports">{{Cite news|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/racism-threatens-to-overshadow-the-copa-america|title=Racism Threatens to Overshadow the Copa America {{!}} VICE Sports|work=VICE Sports|accessdate=2017-04-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Brazil === {{see also|Racism in Brazil|Football in Brazil}} Racism in Brazilian football was discussed by the media in the run-up to the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], held in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/wsc-daily/1175-march-2014/11332-racism-causes-concern-in-brazil-ahead-of-world-cup|title=Racism causes concern in Brazil ahead of World Cup|date=15 March 2014|publisher=When Saturday Comes|accessdate=27 March 2014}}</ref>
In September 2014, [[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio]] were banned from competing in the [[Copa do Brasil]] after some of their fans were seen racially abusing an opposition player.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-29052037|title=Brazil football club Gremio banned over racism incident|date=4 September 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref>
===Chile=== Emilio Renteria, of Venezuelan descent was forced off the field crying due to extreme racial abuse during a game played in the Chilean league. After scoring a goal against the opposing team, Renteria celebrated on the side of the pitch. After this the crowd began to chant numerous racist slurs forcing him to leave the game. Chilean senator later apologized to Renteria and made a joint effort to grow awareness for the problem in Chile.<ref name="VICE Sports" />
=== Ecuador === In the 2006 World Cup held in Germany, The Ecuadorian team was the target of racism by a German commentator. The commentator was said to have commented on the color of the Ecuadorians dark skin. After this statement, the commentator continued, saying that the Ecuadorians were not real Ecuadorians, and were from Nigeria. His comments started an uproar in Ecuador over national identity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rahier|first=Jean Muteba|date=2010-06-27|title=Red Card: Soccer and Racism (review)|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/384152|journal=The Americas|language=en|volume=67|issue=1|pages=151–152|doi=10.1353/tam.0.0290|issn=1533-6247}}</ref>
=== Peru === Jhoel Herrera a player for Real Garcilaso of the Peruvian first division brought family to his opponent's home stadium to celebrate mother's day. Herrera endured 90 minutes of racist verbal abuse from the opposing fans and players while the ref seemed to not react. At the end of the game, Herrera's mother was caught on tape being physically abused by the racist opposing team's fans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/racism-threatens-to-overshadow-the-copa-america|title=Racism and the Copa America|last=Montes|first=Euclides|date=|website=|accessdate=}}</ref>

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Dr. Robert J. Goldstein''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Conspiracies (Television)|conspirator]] who plotted with two accomplices to destroy the Islamic Education Center in [[Pinellas County]], [[Florida]] with homemade [[C-4 (explosive)|C4]].{{when?|date=January 2017}} A police search of the Goldstein home found a list of 50 Islamic worship centers on Florida, home-made explosives and a mission statement to "Kill all rags".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/US/08/23/florida.explosives/index.html |title=Florida man plotted mosque attacks, feds say |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=2006-12-18 | date=2002-08-23}}</ref> Goldstein admitted that he planned to destroy the center and plead guilty to conspiracy to violate civil rights, conspiracy to damage religious property, and possession of unlicensed [[destructive device]]s. He was sentenced to 12 years and 7 months in Federal prison.
Ahmed Bedier, a spokesman for the [[Council for American-Islamic Relations]] who worshipped at the Pinellas County mosque, alleged double standards in the treatment of Goldstein and argued that Goldstein should have been prosecuted as a terrorist, but prosecutors said the facts of the case didn't warrant such a charge. "I'm happy he's behind bars and will serve some time, but it's nowhere enough for the damage he intended to do," Bedier said."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cair-florida.org/podiatrist_guilty.htm |title=Podiatrist Pleads Guilty in Plot to Attack Islamic Center |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=2006-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007071622/http://www.cair-florida.org/podiatrist_guilty.htm |archivedate=October 7, 2007}}</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=January 2010}}
On the afternoon of July 16, 2003, George Weller, then age 86, drove his 1992 [[Buick LeSabre]] westbound down Arizona Avenue in [[Santa Monica, California]] toward the city's popular [[Third Street Promenade]]. The last few blocks of the street, before it ends at the ocean, had been closed to vehicle traffic for the biweekly [[farmers' market]].
Weller's car struck a 2003 [[Mercedes-Benz S-Class|Mercedes-Benz S430]] sedan that had stopped to allow pedestrians through a crosswalk, then accelerated around a road closure sign, crashed through wooden sawhorses, and plowed through the busy marketplace crowd, traveling nearly {{convert|1000|ft}} at speeds between {{convert|40|and|60|mph|abbr=on|-1}}. The entire sequence of collisions took at least 10 seconds.
By the time the car came to a halt, ten people had been killed and 63 were injured. Weller told investigators he had accidentally placed his foot on the accelerator pedal instead of the brake, then tried to brake but could not stop. Days after the crash, Weller issued a statement saying he was distraught and heartbroken, and his attorney called it an accident.
The crash fueled a national debate in the [[United States]] on safety risks posed by [[elderly drivers]].
Some observers questioned Weller's account; numerous witnesses and victims reported: * Seeing no brake lights on Weller's car, which would indicate that he was not attempting to stop;{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} * Weller stared straight ahead as he drove through the crowd, with victims flying over his windshield;{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} * Weller angrily yelled from his car "Get out of the way!" as he hit pedestrians;<ref name=NextEngine>Eyewitness accounts from employees of NextEngine Inc. (2003-07-16 and 17)</ref> * That Weller avoided parked cars and produce tables on both sides of the road, steering instead directly down the middle of the crowded street;{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} * Weller did strike one vegetable stand, "sandwiching" victims with shelves and structural components from the stand;<ref name="NextEngine"/> * Weller's car came to a stop after hitting two parked cars;<ref name="NextEngine"/>
Weller's supporters{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} argue that: * Weller suffered from [[arthritis]], [[nausea]] as a side-effect of medication, and reduced mobility from a [[hip replacement]]. * Weller had a relatively clean driving record at the [[Department of Motor Vehicles|DMV]], with one minor crash and no violations. Weller had passed a vision test and written test on renewing his driver's license in November 2000. * Since the tragedy resulted from a "misapplication" of the pedal, Weller had committed an accident, not a crime. "Pedal error cannot constitute negligence," stated Mark Overland, an attorney for Weller.
After he was found guilty of ten counts of [[vehicular manslaughter]], the sentencing judge noted that Weller "showed enormous indifference" and "unbelievable callousness."<ref name=LAT052208>{{cite web|author= Richard Winton and Martha Groves |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/22/local/me-market22 |title= Case is closed on deadly day at market |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=May 22, 2008 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}}</ref>
This case became the inspiration for the [[South Park]] [[South Park (season 7)|Season 7]] episode "[[Grey Dawn]]".
==Aftermath timeline== The day of the tragedy in Santa Monica, footage of a previous crash Weller had been in ten years earlier surfaced. While that crash was not fatal, he had driven his car off the road in much the same fashion as the Promenade crash and the footage was nearly identical in that it showed a confused Weller wandering around his crashed car in a heavily populated, public area. This further sparked debate surrounding what warning signs authorities should examine when dealing with driving privileges and the elderly.
On July 24, 2003, it was reported that state officials revoked Weller's driver's license.
On January 5, 2004, the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office charged George Russell Weller with ten counts of vehicular manslaughter with gross negligence, carrying a penalty of up to 18 years in prison. Weller's attorneys were ordered to surrender their client within 24 hours.
On January 6, 2004, Weller pleaded not guilty to the charges before Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Paula Adele Mabrey and was released on his own recognizance.
On January 14, 2004, victims and relatives filed suit against the City of Santa Monica and Bayside District Corp., organizers of the Santa Monica farmers' market, alleging that the crash could have been prevented by the installation of metal barriers. Attorney Geoff Wells, representing victims and their relatives, remarked that "[The defendants] failed to take any reasonable steps to provide protection for the patrons at the farmer's market."
On October 25, 2004, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Katherine Mader convened a preliminary hearing to determine whether Weller would stand trial.
On November 3, 2004, Weller was ordered to stand trial, and his arraignment was scheduled for November 17.
On December 8, 2004, after a delay due to poor health, Weller was arraigned, again pleaded not guilty to the charges, and waived his right to a speedy trial.
On March 18, 2005, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Robert O'Neill denied a motion by Weller's attorneys to dismiss the manslaughter charges, remarking that "hitting the accelerator instead of the brake seems to me to be a clearly negligent act."
On October 20, 2006, by a unanimous verdict, jurors found Weller guilty on all charges, convicting him of vehicular manslaughter for killing 10 pedestrians. The sentence was to be decided by the Court, with a maximum penalty of 18 years.
On November 20, 2006, Weller received probation on all counts after a judge determined that Weller was too ill to go to prison, where he would likely be a burden on prison authorities and taxpayers. Weller was a month short of his 90th birthday. He was also ordered to pay more than $100,000 in fines and restitution to the victims' families.
On May 22, 2008, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported that the City of Santa Monica had thus far paid out $21 million to settle dozens of civil lawsuits stemming from the case. The same article also noted that Weller, age 91, was now confined to his home and receiving 24-hour nursing care.<ref name=LAT052208/>
On December 9, 2010, George Russell Weller died at age 94, a mere two days after his 94th birthday.
