|collapse = no }} '''Yi Jianlian''' ({{zh|t=易建聯|s=易建联||p=Yì Jiànlián}} {{IPAc-cmn|yi|4|-|j|ian|4|l|ian|2}}; born October 27, 1984){{cite web|url=http://sports.sohu.com/20081219/n261307196.shtml |title=易建联年龄水落石出 学籍表毕业照暴露秘密(图) |work=Sohu.com |date=December 19, 2008 |accessdate=August 17, 2016 |language=zh |deadurl=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222044235/http://sports.sohu.com/20081219/n261307196.shtml |archivedate=December 22, 2008 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://news.cctv.com/sports/basketball/nba/20070810/101602.shtml |title=易建联谎言被揭穿 真实年龄铁证曝光 即将23岁 |work=CCTV.com |date=August 10, 2007 |accessdate=April 12, 2008 |language=zh |deadurl=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012193432/http://news.cctv.com/sports/basketball/nba/20070810/101602.shtml |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://stats.nba.com/player/#!/201146/ |title=Jianlian Yi |work=NBA.com |accessdate=August 17, 2016}} is a Chinese professional [[basketball]] player for the [[Guangdong Southern Tigers]] of the [[Chinese Basketball Association]] (CBA). He has also played in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) for the [[Milwaukee Bucks]], [[New Jersey Nets]], [[Washington Wizards]] and [[Dallas Mavericks]]. Yi joined the Guangdong Southern Tigers for the [[2002–03 CBA season]], and subsequently won the CBA Rookie of the Year award. In his first five years with Guangdong, the team won three CBA titles. In the [[2007 NBA draft]], he was selected by the Milwaukee Bucks with the sixth overall pick. Initially, Yi declined to sign with Milwaukee for several months before agreeing to a contract with them on 29 August 2007. He later played for three other NBA teams until returning to the Guangdong Southern Tigers in 2012. Yi also plays for the [[China men's national basketball team|Chinese national team]], having represented his country at the [[Basketball at the Summer Olympics|Olympics]] in [[Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2004]], [[Basketball at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2008]], [[Basketball at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012]] and [[Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2016]], as well as the [[2006 FIBA World Championship|2006]] and [[2010 FIBA World Championship]]s. == CBA career == {{Expand section|date=August 2016}} As a child, Yi's parents did not allow him to join a sports school, which is designed for children predicted to be future professional athletes. However, a sports school's basketball coach who noticed Yi's potential in playing street basketball persuaded Yi's family to allow him to train professionally.{{cite news |url=http://www.china.org.cn/english/2003/Sep/75681.htm |title=Little Giant Yi Jianlian: I Want to Play NBA Basketball |last=Li |first=Xiao |date=September 22, 2003 |publisher=China.org.cn |accessdate=2009-02-09}} Hoping to sign Yi to an endorsement deal, [[Adidas]] invited him to attend the company's ABCD camp in New Jersey in 2002, where he competed against all-American high school players.{{cite web |title=NBA.com : Yi Jianlian Bio Page |publisher=NBA.com |url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/yi_jianlian/bio.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105060300/http://www.nba.com/playerfile/yi_jianlian/bio.html |archivedate=2012-11-05 |deadurl=yes}} After returning to China later that year, he signed a professional contract with [[Chinese Basketball Association]] side [[Guangdong Southern Tigers]] and averaged 3.5 points and 1.9 rebounds per game in his first season. He also averaged 7.3 points and 7.3 rebounds per game in four games during the playoffs, and won the Rookie of the Year award. Yi was featured in ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]''{{'}}s August 2003 article titled "The Next [[Yao Ming]]".{{cite news |first=Brook |last=Larmer |url=http://www.time.com/time/covers/1101030908/xyi.html |title=What's Next? |date=August 24, 2003 |accessdate=2007-05-02 | work=Time}} In each of his next three seasons, Yi led Guangdong to the CBA championship and he was awarded [[CBA Finals MVP|the CBA finals' most valuable player]] honor in 2006.{{cite web |title=2006 FIBA World Championships |url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fe/06_wcm/teamPlay/play/p/competitioncode//eventid/3507/langlc/en/playernumber/44281/roundid/3507/season/0/teamnumber/262/fe_teamPlay_playProf.html |accessdate=2007-05-25 }} In Yi's final season in the Chinese Basketball Association before he entered the [[2007 NBA draft]], he averaged a career-high 24.9 points and 11.5 rebounds per game, but his team lost to the [[Bayi Rockets]] in the playoff finals. During the [[2011 NBA lockout]], Yi signed a one-year contract to return to the Guangdong Southern Tigers. Unlike most NBA players who went to the Chinese Basketball Association during that time, he received an option to return to the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] once the lockout had been resolved.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/sports/2011-10/08/content_13852028.htm|title=NBA star Yi Jianlian back to China-Stars-chinadaily.com.cn|publisher=|accessdate=July 20, 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nba/news?slug=aw-wojnarowski_china_nba_players_112811 |title=China could block NBA players return |first=Adrian |last=Wojnarowski |work=Yahoo! Sports |date=November 29, 2011 |accessdate=November 29, 2011}} After the lockout ended, he signed with the [[Dallas Mavericks]] for the remainder of the [[2011–12 NBA season|2011–12 season]]. Yi re-joined the Guangdong Southern Tigers for the [[2012–13 CBA season]]{{cite news|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/2012-09/25/content_15780793.htm|title=No Chinese in NBA as Yi returns to CBA|author= Sun Xiaochen|work=China Daily|date=September 25, 2012|accessdate=September 25, 2012}} and went on to win a fourth championship that season. In October 2016, Yi returned to Guangdong after spending training camp with the [[Los Angeles Lakers]].{{cite news|first=Huberto|last=Meersmans|url=http://nbadestiny.com/yi-jianlian-regresa-china-tras-pedir-los-lakers-le-cortaran/|title=YI JIANLIAN REGRESA A CHINA TRAS PEDIR A LOS LAKERS QUE LE CORTARAN|work=NBADestiny.com|date=October 30, 2016|accessdate=November 5, 2016|language=Spanish}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == NBA career == === NBA draft === Yi was not expected to enter the [[NBA draft]] until 2009 because the [[Chinese Basketball Association]] ruled that players are not allowed to leave for foreign leagues until they turned 22.{{cite news |first=Zhau |last=Rui |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/sports/2006-11/03/content_723586.htm |title=Yi can enter 2007 NBA draft |date=November 3, 2006 |accessdate=2007-03-02 }} In early 2006, however, Yi announced that he would enter the [[2006 NBA draft]] although he eventually decided to withdraw, saying he was "not good enough to compete in the NBA and needed more experience."{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2006-04/20/content_4451142.htm |title=China's Yi Jianlian not ready for NBA yet |date=April 20, 2006 |accessdate=2007-05-25}} Later that year, the [[Guangdong Southern Tigers]] announced that Yi would enter the [[2007 NBA draft]].{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2648042 |title=Chinese prospect Yi gets permission to enter '07 draft |date=November 3, 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-18}} Yi chose [[Dan Fegan]] as his agent to represent him in the NBA draft and flew to Los Angeles to participate in pre-NBA draft camps.{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Sheridan|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2654250 |title=Fegan will represent Yi for contract, marketing |date=November 8, 2006 |accessdate=2007-05-25 }} Before the draft, Yi was predicted by many to be picked anywhere from third to twelfth.{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/features/draft2007_consensus.html |title=NBA Draft 2007: What's the Consensus? |publisher=NBA.com |date=June 9, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-12 }} On 28 June 2007, Yi was selected by the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] with the sixth overall pick in the 2007 NBA draft, despite Fegan warning the Milwaukee Bucks not to pick Yi and not allowing them to be one of the teams invited to Yi's pre-draft private workouts in Los Angeles. Fegan did not want Milwaukee to select Yi because the city of Milwaukee did not have a large Asian-American community.{{cite news | last = Gardner | first = Charles F. | title = Yi finally signs with the Bucks | publisher = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] Online | date = August 29, 2007 | url = http://www.jsonline.com/sports/bucks/29465909.html | accessdate = 2008-04-06 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110606003307/http://www.jsonline.com/sports/bucks/29465909.html | archivedate = June 6, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} However, Milwaukee's general manager [[Larry Harris (basketball)|Larry Harris]] said they had only drafted the best player available to them. Yi and [[Sun Yue (basketball)|Sun Yue]] together marked the first time in NBA draft history where two Chinese born players were selected in the same draft, which was a feat that would not be repeated again until [[2016 NBA draft|2016]]. After the draft, Milwaukee attempted to convince Yi to sign with the team and on 2 July 2007, the owner of the Bucks franchise, [[Herb Kohl]], wrote a letter to Yi and his representatives, hoping to persuade Yi to sign with the team.{{cite news | last = Marcus | first = David | title = Senator Asks Chinese Star to Consider Bucks | publisher = todaystmj4.com | date = July 1, 2007 | url = http://www.todaystmj4.com/sports/local/8265907.html | accessdate = 2008-04-06 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071009103637/http://www.todaystmj4.com/sports/local/8265907.html | archivedate = October 9, 2007 | df = mdy-all }} Three days later, head coach [[Larry Krystkowiak]] and Harris met with Yi, attempting to influence him to play for Milwaukee,{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=2928521 |title=Bucks meet with Yi in Las Vegas, begin lobbying |date=July 6, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-05 }} however, Yi's representatives requested that the team trade Yi to another team with a city that had a large Chinese presence. Chinese officials also required that any team Yi played for would have to give him sufficient playing time for him to improve for the [[Basketball at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Summer Olympics]]. Kohl made a special trip to Hong Kong to appeal to Yi personally{{cite news |title=Milwaukee brass signs Yi Jianlian on Hong Kong trip |work=[[USA Today]] | date = August 29, 2007 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/sports/basketball/nba/bucks/2007-08-29-yi-signing_N.htm | accessdate = 2008-04-06 }} and he assured Chinese officials that Yi would have sufficient playing time. On 29 August 2007, the Milwaukee Bucks and Yi agreed to a standard, multi-year rookie contract. === Milwaukee Bucks === [[File:YiJianlianfreethrow.jpg|thumb|right|Yi attempting a free throw against the [[Portland Trail Blazers]]]] Yi was named to Milwaukee's starting lineup by head coach [[Larry Krystkowiak]] in place of [[Charlie Villanueva]] to begin the [[2007–08 NBA season|2007–08 season]].{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=3086147 |title=Rookie to start Bucks' opener; Villanueva to come off bench |publisher=ESPN.com |date=October 30, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} He recorded nine points and three rebounds in a debut loss to the [[Orlando Magic]].{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nba/recap?gid=2007103119|title=Lewis, Turkoglu lead Magic 3-point barrage in 102-83 victory over Milwaukee|work=Yahoo! Sports! |date=October 31, 2007|accessdate=2009-09-15}} He played his first home game in Milwaukee three days later and scored 16 points while grabbing eight boards in a 78–72 win over the [[Chicago Bulls]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/games/20071103/CHIMIL/recap.html |title=Redd, Yi Lead Bucks Past Bulls |publisher=NBA.com |date=November 4, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} The game was also Yi's first game to be televised nationally in China, where it was watched by an estimated 100 million viewers.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/sports/2007-11/05/content_6231752.htm |title=Chinese media hail Yi's NBA game |publisher=China Daily |date=November 5, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} [[Yao Ming]] praised Yi's play in his first few games, saying, "If you compare us in our third NBA games, you will see that Yi's statistics are far better than mine." On 9 November 2007, Yi played against Yao for the first time when the [[Houston Rockets]] hosted Milwaukee in a 104–88 loss. Yi recorded 19 points and nine rebounds, including two three-pointers, while Yao recorded 28 points and nine rebounds.{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/games/20071109/MILHOU/recap.html |title=Yao's Rockets Beat Yi's Bucks |publisher=NBA.com |date=November 10, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} The game between the two was watched by over 200 million people in China, making it one of the most-watched games in NBA history. After the game, Yao called Yi's talent "unbelievable" and [[Tracy McGrady]] said that Yi had a "tremendous upside in this league". [[Del Harris]], the former head coach of the [[China men's national basketball team|Chinese national basketball team]], also described Yi as the "most athletic 7-footer in the NBA."{{cite news |last=Ludden |first=Johnny |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nba/news?slug=jy-yaoyi110907&prov=yhoo&type=lgns |title=Rookie Yi impresses elder statesman Yao |work=Yahoo! Sports |date=November 10, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} Yi was named the NBA Rookie of the Month for December 2007 after averaging 12.1 points and 6.6 rebounds per game that month,{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/news/rookies_080102.html |title=Yi, Durant Named Rookies of the Month |publisher=NBA.com |date=January 2, 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} while scoring a career-high 29 points on 14-of-17 shooting in a win over the [[Charlotte Bobcats]] on December 22.{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/games/20071222/CHAMIL/recap.html |title=Yi Scores Career-High 29, Leads Bucks Over Bobcats |publisher=NBA.com |date=December 23, 2007 |accessdate=2008-04-19}} On 30 January 2008, he was selected for the rookie team in the [[Rookie Challenge]] at the [[2008 NBA All-Star Game]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/allstar2008/rookie_sophomore_080130.html |title=Roy Headlines T-Mobile Rookie Challenge & Youth Jam |publisher=NBA.com |date=January 30, 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} On 2 February 2008, Yi faced Yao for the second time when Milwaukee played at home against Houston, which Krystkowiak dubbed the "Chinese Super Bowl."{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/games/20080202/HOUMIL/recap.html |title=McGrady Sparks Rockets' Offense |publisher=NBA.com |date=February 2, 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-10}} However, both players struggled during Houston's 91–83 victory over Milwaukee. Yao scored 12 points while Yi injured his shoulder during the game, finishing with just six points. On 2 April 2008, it was announced that Yi would miss the rest of the season with a knee injury.{{cite news |last=Elund |first=Tom |url=http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=735767 |title=Knee injury forces Yi out for rest of season |publisher=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |date=April 2, 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080409142528/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=735767 |archivedate = April 9, 2008}} Having already missed eight games with other injuries, Yi managed 66 out of a possible 82 games in his rookie season, averaging 8.6 points and 5.2 rebounds per game.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/yi_jianlian/ |title=Yi Jianlian Info Page |publisher=NBA.com |accessdate=2008-04-10}} One of Milwaukee's assistant coaches, [[Brian James (basketball)|Brian James]], later said that "the injuries he had bothered him more than people realized, and he couldn't play through them."{{cite news |first=Dave |last=D'Alessandro |url=http://www.nj.com/sports/index.ssf/2008/10/its_a_tough_call_but_new_jerse.html |title=It's a tough call, but New Jersey Nets banking on Yi |publisher=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=October 25, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-25}} === New Jersey Nets === On 26 June 2008, Yi was traded by the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] along with [[Bobby Simmons]] to the [[New Jersey Nets]] in exchange for [[Richard Jefferson]].{{cite web |title=Nets acquire Yi Jianlian and Bobby Simmons from Milwaukee in exchange for Richard Jefferson |publisher=NBA.com |url=http://www.nba.com/nets/news/Yi_Trade-276058-64.html |accessdate=2008-06-26 }} New Jersey's team president [[Rod Thorn]] said that "we feel strongly he's going to be a real good player,"{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/draft2008/news/story?id=3462210 |title=Nets send top scorer Jefferson to Bucks for Yi, Simmons |date=June 27, 2008 |publisher=ESPN.com |accessdate=2009-02-08}} and the team's chief executive Brett Yormark said "it opens up a truly new fan base for us."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/28/sports/basketball/28nets.html?n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/Subjects/B/Basketball |title=By Adding Yi, Nets Hope to Expand Their Market |last=Robinson |first=Joshua |date=June 28, 2008 |work=New York Times |accessdate=2009-02-08}} Yi stated that he didn't expect to be traded, but that it was "an honor to join the Nets."{{cite news |url=http://en.beijing2008.cn/news/sports/headlines/basketball/n214424294.shtml |title=Yi, Simmons traded for Richard Jefferson |publisher=beijing2008.cn |accessdate=2009-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080902042813/http://en.beijing2008.cn/news/sports/headlines/basketball/n214424294.shtml |archivedate=September 2, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Through his first 37 games with New Jersey, Yi averaged 10.5 points and 6.2 rebounds per game while shooting 39% from behind the three-point line, which was well above his average from the previous season.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/yi_jianlian/career_stats.html |title=Yi Jianlian Career Stats Page |publisher=NBA.com |accessdate=2009-02-08 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ac7E55tN?url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/yi_jianlian/career_stats.html |archive-date=September 12, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} But on 9 January 2009, Yi broke the little finger on his right hand and was expected to miss four to six weeks.{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/basketball/nets/2009/01/10/2009-01-10_yi_jianlian__nets_find_that_pinkie_injur.html |title=Yi Jianlian & Nets find that pinkie injury is bad break |last=Garcia |first=Julian |date=January 11, 2009 |work=[[Daily News (New York)]] |accessdate=2009-02-08}} Thorn called it "lousy timing" because "he'd been playing well," but Yi said "(I'll) just take my time. I'll come back." In voting for the [[2009 NBA All-Star Game]], Yi finished third in total votes for forwards in the Eastern Conference, ahead of players such as [[Paul Pierce]] and [[Chris Bosh]]. Yi made his return from injury after the 2009 NBA All-Star Game in a loss to the [[Houston Rockets]] on 17 February 2009.{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/games/20090217/NJNHOU/recap.html |title=Battier, Yao lead Rockets past Nets 114-88 |last=Duncan |first=Chris |date=February 17, 2009 |publisher=NBA.com |accessdate=2009-04-07}} However, after averaging only six points on 36% shooting after his return, Yi was removed from the team's starting lineup.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.nypost.com/sports/nets/archives/2009/03/yi_out_anderson.html |title=Yi Out, Anderson In, Devin Gametime |last=Kerber |first=Fred |date=March 27, 2009 |work=New York Post |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411100641/http://blogs.nypost.com/sports/nets/archives/2009/03/yi_out_anderson.html |archivedate=April 11, 2009 }} His final averages for the season were 8.6 points and 5.3 rebounds per game, as well as a 38% shooting percentage from the field and 34% on three-point field goals. After New Jersey finished the season outside of the playoffs,{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/standings?season=2009|title=NBA Standings – 2008–2009 |publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-05-14}} Yi's agent [[Dan Fegan]] suggested New Jersey played better when Yi played more minutes and took more shots, and said it "begs the question[sic]...who's accountable?" New Jersey's head coach [[Lawrence Frank]] said that "you have to be patient. He's only 21", and Yi assessed his season by saying he was "still too much up and down."{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/nets/index.ssf/2009/04/agent_suggests_new_jersey_nets.html|title=Agent suggests New Jersey Nets are to blame for Yi Jianlian's stalled development|last=D'Allesandro|first=Dave|date=April 12, 2009|publisher=New Jersey Star-Ledger|accessdate=2009-05-14}} In the [[2009–10 NBA season|2009–10 season]], Yi returned to the starting lineup for New Jersey. Starting in every game he played but one,{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/j/jianlyi01.html|title=Yi Jianlian|work=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=February 3, 2016}} Yi suffered several injuries during the season which made him miss 30 games. He sprained his medial collateral ligament on 4 November 2009, had a laceration on his upper lip on 8 December 2009, and sprained his left ankle on 8 March 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/yi_jianlian/bio.html|title=NBA.com/Stats|publisher=|accessdate=February 3, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/NJN/2010_games.html|title=2009–10 New Jersey Nets|work=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=February 3, 2016}} His final averages for the season were 12 points and 7.2 rebounds per game, as well as a 40% shooting percentage from the field and 37% on three-point field goals. === Washington Wizards === On 29 June 2010, Yi was traded to the [[Washington Wizards]] along with $3 million in cash considerations for [[Quinton Ross]].{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/new-york/nba/news/story?id=5340026|title=New Jersey Nets send Yi Jianlian to Washington Wizards for Quinton Ross|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=February 3, 2016}} Yi ended the [[2010–11 NBA season|2010–11 season]] averaging 5.6 points and 3.9 rebounds per game. Washington had until 30 June 2011 to extend Yi's contract but decided not to.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wizards-insider/post/wizards-pick-up-rookie-options-extend-qualifying-offer-to-nick-young-but-not-yi-jianlian/2011/06/18/AG4M8daH_blog.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Stats, scores and schedules | date=June 18, 2011}} === Dallas Mavericks === On 6 January 2012, Yi signed with the [[Dallas Mavericks]] to a one-year contract after starting the season with the [[Guangdong Southern Tigers]].{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/dallas/nba/story/_/id/7432700/dallas-mavericks-sign-forward-yi-jianlian-one-year-contract|title=Mavericks sign forward Yi Jianlian|date=January 6, 2012|work=ESPN}} He was immediately assigned to Dallas' [[NBA Development League|D-League]] affiliate team, the [[Texas Legends]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/dleague/news/dallas_mavericks_assign_yi_jia_2012_01_06.html|title=Dallas Mavericks Assign Yi Jianlian to Texas Legends|date=January 6, 2012|work=NBA|access-date=January 7, 2012|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ac7Fpkgt?url=http://www.nba.com/dleague/news/dallas_mavericks_assign_yi_jia_2012_01_06.html|archive-date=September 12, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Yi benefited from the new collective bargaining agreement rules which allowed players with more than two years of NBA experience to be assigned to the D-League with the players' consent.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/dleague/news/nba_cba_boosts_nba_dleague_2011_12_08.html|title=NBA Collective Bargaining Agreement Seen Giving Boost To NBA Development League|date=December 8, 2011|work=NBA}} On 9 January 2012, after playing two games for the Texas Legends, averaging 23 points and 12 rebounds per game, he was recalled by Dallas.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/2012/news/01/09/mavs-yi-jianlian.ap/index.html|title=Mavs recall Yi Jianlian from D-League affiliate|date=January 9, 2012|work=NBA|access-date=January 31, 2012|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ac7H59HY?url=http://www.nba.com/2012/news/01/09/mavs-yi-jianlian.ap/index.html|archive-date=September 12, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/dallas/mavericks/post/_/id/4683274/yi-jianlian-will-join-mavs-in-detroit|title=Yi Jianlian will join Mavs in Detroit|date=December 9, 2011|work=ESPN}} The team faced the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]] in the playoffs and in Game 3 of the playoff series, Yi played in his first NBA playoffs game, where he scored two points for the team in five minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20120503/OKCDAL/gameinfo.html|title=Mavs-Thunder box score|date=May 3, 2012|work=NBA}} === Attempted return to NBA === On August 22, 2016, Yi signed a one-year, $8 million contract with the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], returning to the NBA for the first time since 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/160822jianlian|title=Lakers Sign Yi Jianlian|work=NBA.com|date=August 22, 2016|accessdate=August 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last=Britton|first=Patrick|url=https://www.thescore.com/nba/news/1079756-report-lakers-yi-jianlian-finalizing-1-year-8m-deal|title=Report: Lakers, Yi Jianlian finalizing 1-year, $8M deal|work=TheScore.com|date=August 17, 2016|accessdate=August 29, 2016}} Lakers head coach [[Luke Walton]] considered Yi to be the team's best-shooting big man during the preseason, but did not provide Yi with much of a role. Yi averaged 3.0 points and 2.5 rebounds in 10.7 minutes per game over six contests with the Lakers during the preseason. Feeling he would have better opportunities elsewhere, Yi requested a release from the Lakers prior to the start of the regular season.{{cite web|last=Ganguli|first=Tania|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/lakers/la-sp-lakers-yi-jianlian-20161024-snap-story.html|title=Yi Jianlian asks for his release from the Lakers|work=LATimes.com|date=October 24, 2016|accessdate=October 24, 2016}} The Lakers waived him on October 24, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/161024yi-jianlian-waived|title=Lakers Waive Yi Jianlian|work=NBA.com|date=October 24, 2016|accessdate=October 24, 2016}} == National team career == Yi's first major international experience came at the [[2003 FIBA Under-19 World Championship]] in which he averaged 18.9 points and 11.5 rebounds per game. He made his debut with the [[Chinese men's national basketball team|Chinese national basketball team]] during the [[Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2004 Summer Olympics]] and averaged 6 points and 6 rebounds per game at the [[2006 FIBA World Championship]]. His performance impressed coaches on the Chinese national team as well as the coaches from other countries.{{cite news |url=http://usabasketball.com/seniormen/2006/06_mwc_exhibition_game2_quotes.html |title=USA-China Post Game Quotes (August 7, 2006) |publisher=USA Basketball |date=August 7, 2006 |accessdate=2006-09-07 }} In 2008, Yi was once again selected to play for the Chinese national team at the [[Basketball at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2008 Summer Olympics]]. In China's first two group stage matches, Yi scored 9 and 4 points respectively, and China lost both their games against the [[United States men's national basketball team|United States]] and [[Spain men's national basketball team|Spain]].{{cite web |url=http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B03.shtml#BKM400B03 |title=Results Men's Preliminary Round Group B- Game 12 / United StatesUSA 101 vs 70 ChinaCHN |publisher=beijing2008.cn |accessdate=2009-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813020650/http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B03.shtml#BKM400B03 |archivedate=August 13, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B05.shtml#BKM400B05 |title=Results Men's Preliminary Round Group B- Game 22 / ChinaCHN 75 vs 85 SpainESP |publisher=beijing2008.cn |accessdate=2009-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080815033023/http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B05.shtml#BKM400B05 |archivedate=August 15, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} But in a win against [[Angola national basketball team|Angola]], Yi recorded a double-double,{{cite news |url=http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B08.shtml#BKM400B08 |title=Results: Men's Preliminary Round Group B- Game 33 |publisher=beijing2008.cn |date=August 14, 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817040207/http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B08.shtml#BKM400B08 |archivedate=August 17, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} and in a win against [[Germany national basketball team|Germany]], Yi recorded 9 points and 11 rebounds,{{cite news |url=http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B11.shtml#BKM400B11 |title=Results: Men's Preliminary Round Group B- Game 47 |publisher=beijing2008.cn |date=August 16, 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819022514/http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400B11.shtml#BKM400B11 |archivedate=August 19, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} and hit the crucial shot with 28 seconds left to help China advance to the quarter-finals.{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/sports/5948367.html |title=Yao leads China over Germany at Olympics |last=Blinebury |first=Fran |date=August 16, 2008 |work=Houston Chronicle |accessdate=2009-02-08}} However, [[Lithuania men's national basketball team|Lithuania]] ended China's run by beating them 94–68, as Yi scored 11 points for his side.{{cite news |url=http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400302.shtml#BKM400302 |title=Results: Men's Quarterfinal – Game 66 |publisher=beijing2008.cn |date=August 20, 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107180914/http://results.beijing2008.cn/WRM/ENG/INF/BK/C73/BKM400302.shtml#BKM400302 |archivedate=January 7, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} Yi, along with former NBA player [[Sun Yue (basketball)|Sun Yue]], was a member of the Chinese national team that played at the [[2009 FIBA Asia Championship]] and the [[2011 FIBA Asia Championship]].{{cite news|url=http://www.fibaasia.net/cms/info.php?itemid=13 |title=Information – FIBA Asian Calendar Events 2009 |publisher=fibaasia.net |accessdate=November 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519111345/http://www.fibaasia.net/cms/info.php?itemid=13 |archivedate=May 19, 2009 }} Yi was named [[FIBA Asia Cup MVP|the most valuable player of the 2011 FIBA Asia Championship]], averaging 16.6 points and 10.8 rebounds per game.{{cite web |url=http://wuhan2011.fibaasia.net/TournamentNewsDetails.aspx?id=1395 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108015412/http://wuhan2011.fibaasia.net/TournamentNewsDetails.aspx?id=1395 |archivedate=November 8, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}http://wuhan2011.fibaasia.net/Player_Accumalated_Statistics.aspx?id=44281{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Yi also played for the Chinese national team during the [[Basketball at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Summer Olympics]], ranking first in rebounds per game with 10.2 per game and ranking second in blocks with 2.2 per game.{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/sports/2012-07/26/c_123474498.htm}} He also played at the [[Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2016 Summer Olympics]]. == Off the court == [[File:YiJianlianworkout.jpg|thumb|right|Yi during the [[2007–08 NBA season]].]] === Personal life === Yi is fluent in both [[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin]] and his native tongue of [[Standard Cantonese|Cantonese]]. He was ranked fourth on ''[[Forbes]]''' [[China Celebrity 100]] in income and popularity in 2008.{{cite news |title=Yao Ming leads Forbes' Chinese celebrity list for fifth year |publisher=Xinhau |date=March 11, 2008 |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-03/11/content_7767648.htm |accessdate=2008-03-16}} In 2008, Yi donated 100,000 yuan to support the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]] victims{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-05/14/content_8170993.htm |title=Chinese athletes donate to earthquake-hit area |date=May 14, 2008 |publisher=Xinhau |accessdate=2008-05-16}} and also participated in the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]' torch relay by carrying the torch during the Hainan leg of the relay.{{cite web |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jLq-4FXUr41vEFVFfIpmovJYZBrQ |title=China welcomes home Olympic flame |date=May 4, 2008 |publisher=[[Google News]] |accessdate=2008-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ac7JdH9i?url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jLq-4FXUr41vEFVFfIpmovJYZBrQ |archivedate=September 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} === Age controversy === In 2004, Yi was listed as being born in 1984 during the Four Nation Tournament,{{cite news |first=Aran |last=Smith |publisher=NBADraft.net |url=http://www.nbadraft.net/jianlianstory001.asp |title=Yi Jianlian actually 19 years old |date=July 14, 2004 |accessdate=2007-05-02 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051222120922/http://nbadraft.net/jianlianstory001.asp |archivedate = December 22, 2005}} but Chinese officials said that it was probably a typographical error.{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/sports/2004-07/19/content_1613379.htm |script-title=zh:美媒体再炒易建联年龄 一夜老了三岁潜力不再 |date=July 19, 2004 |accessdate=2008-04-01 |language=zh}} Two years later, Fran Blinebury of ''[[The Houston Chronicle]]'' reported that Yi told [[Shane Battier]] he was 24 years old in an exhibition game before the [[2006 FIBA World Championship]],{{cite news |first=Fran |last=Blinebury |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2006_4178585 |title=China rushing to match talent on court before 2008 Olympics |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=August 26, 2006 |accessdate=2007-03-12 }} but the story was refuted by both Yi and Battier.{{cite news |url=http://sports.eastday.com/eastday/sports/node72135/node72431/node72432/node76273/u1a2285195.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703142118/http://sports.eastday.com/eastday/sports/node72135/node72431/node72432/node76273/u1a2285195.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 3, 2007 |script-title=zh:年龄问题再次引起争论易建联怒斥巴蒂尔太无聊 |publisher=EastDay.com |date=August 29, 2006 |accessdate=2008-04-11 |language=zh }}{{cite news |url=http://sports.163.com/06/0901/06/2PTQJ7D8000520J1.html |title=巴蒂尔：易建联定有望进入NBA 我不知道他几岁 |publisher=163.com |date=August 29, 2006 |accessdate=2008-04-11 |language=zh}} Yi is not the first Chinese basketball player to come under scrutiny for age discrepancy, as former NBA player [[Wang Zhizhi]] had been listed as being born in both 1977 and 1979.{{cite web |title=ESPN – ZhiZhi Wang Stats, News, and Photos |publisher=ESPN.com |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/players/profile?playerId=972 |accessdate=2008-04-11 }}{{cite web |title=Player profile: Wang Zhizhi, 2006 FIBA World Championship |publisher=FIBA.com |url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fe/06_wcm/teamPlay/play/p/competitioncode//eventid/3507/langlc/en/playernumber/22346/roundid/3507/season/0/teamnumber/262/fe_teamPlay_playProf.html |accessdate=2008-04-11 }} In 2006, a senior Chinese official admitted that past youth squads had included players above the permitted age.{{cite news |title=China admits to age fraud |publisher=[[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox Sports]] |date=November 15, 2006 |url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/story/0,8659,20763990-23769,00.html |accessdate=2008-04-12 }} In 2007 and 2008, Yi's date of birth was further scrutinized as being 27 October 1984, including a Chinese reporter discovering a high school enrollment form from 1997 that listed Yi as being born on 27 October 1984. == Career statistics == === CBA
